content.question: Boyle’s law states that if the temperature of an ideal gas is held constant, then the pressure <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the gas and its volume <math alttext="V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> satisfy the relationship <math alttext="P equals, k over V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is a constant. Which of the following best describes the relationship between the rate of change, with respect to time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, of the pressure and the rate of change, with respect to time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, of the volume?

choices.label: <math alttext="the derivative of P, with respect to t, equals, the fraction with numerator k, and denominator the derivative of v, with respect to t, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="the derivative of P, with respect to t, equals, the fraction with numerator negative k, and denominator the derivative of V, with respect to t, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="the derivative of P, with respect to t, equals, the fraction with numerator k, and denominator V squared, end fraction, times, the derivative of V, with respect to t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="the derivative of P, with respect to t, equals, the fraction with numerator negative k, and denominator V squared, end fraction, times the derivative of V, with respect to t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="the derivative of P, with respect to t, equals, the fraction with numerator negative k, and denominator V squared, end fraction, times the derivative of V, with respect to t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
